channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Google Antitrust Trial Concludes With Closing Arguments
item.description: The first tech monopoly trial of the modern internet era is concluding. The judge’s ruling is likely to set a precedent for other attempts to rein in the tech giants that hold sway over information, social interaction and commerce.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Hopes for Cease-Fire Remain, Despite Hamas’s Resistance to Latest Offer
item.description: Officials are waiting for the group’s response to a proposal with U.S. and Israeli backing for a halt to fighting in Gaza and the release of hostages held there.

item.title: Richard Branson says it’s ‘very sad’ when people measure wealth as success and finds being called a billionaire ‘insulting’
item.description: "Maybe in America, ‘billionaire’ is a sign of success, but that rankles me,” Richard Branson, who has an estimated net worth of $2.6 billion, said.

item.title: Inside the U.C.L.A. Protests, and Trump Holds Rallies Amid Trial
U.S. Accuses Russia of Using Chemical Weapons in Ukraine
item.description: The State Department said Russia had used chloropicrin, a poison gas widely used during World War I against Ukrainian forces, an act that would violate a global ban signed by Moscow.

item.title: Puig is poised for a $15 billion IPO, but CEO Marc Puig has a ‘self-disempowerment’ plan to stop his family from controlling the Spanish beauty empire
item.description: CEO Marc Puig thinks setting "difficult filters" even for family members is the best way to practice "meritocracy."

item.title: How Technology Has Outpaced the Law
item.description: Abortions in the U.S. have risen slightly since Roe was struck down. One factor: pills ordered online.

item.title: A Portrait Artist Fit for a King (but Not a President)
item.description: Jonathan Yeo, about to unveil a major new painting of King Charles III, also counts Hollywood royalty (Nicole Kidman) and prime ministers (Tony Blair) as past subjects. But George W. Bush eluded him.

item.title: AI boom still running hot as SK Hynix says its already sold majority of its 2025 allotment of high-bandwidth memory chips
item.description: Comments from CEO of SK Hynix, the world's second largest memory chipmaker, suggest the shortage of AI-related chips isn't ending anytime soon.

item.title: Biden Loosens Up on Weed
item.description: The U.S. government has recommended easing federal restrictions on the drug that have been in place for decades.

item.title: Bulgarian Distrust of Russia Simmers Over a Black Sea Oil Terminal
item.description: Russia has been losing its grip on the Rosenets Oil Terminal, near the port city of Burgas, as Bulgarian authorities seek to assert greater control over the Russian-run facility.

item.title: To compete with Asia's rising dominance, French billionaire Bollore wants to build an EV battery plant in France
item.description: Vincent Bollore, CEO of investment group Bollore, is “actively working” on developing the plant with a goal of opening it by 2030.

item.title: U.S. Accuses Russia of Using Chemical Weapons in Ukraine
item.description: The State Department said Russia had used chloropicrin, a poison gas widely used during World War I against Ukrainian forces, an act that would violate a global ban signed by Moscow.

item.title: U.S. and Israel Struggle With Clashing Visions on Ending Gaza War
item.description: The Biden administration wants to focus on a cease-fire and rebuilding Gaza, but Israel’s leader is pushing a new offensive.

item.title: ‘Time is running out’ to build more electric truck chargers in Europe
item.description: Daimler Truck, Volkswagen’s Traton, and Volvo are planning to spend $534 million to install at least 1,700 chargers in Europe.
